peppermining.conformance.conformance module

class peppermining.conformance.conformance.Conformance(data: PepperMining | PepperFilter, models: ProcessModel | list)[source]

Bases: object

Conformance Checker.

The conformance checker allows you to automatically compare a reference process model with the actual process flows discovered from the data. The difference between the model and actual flows is returned in the dataframe with a diagnostics column.

_component

PepperMining or PepperFilter object.

Type:

pd.DataFrame

_models

List of ProcessModel objects.

Type:

list

_conformance_list

DataFrame with conformance details.

Type:

pd.DataFrame

get_cases()[source]

Return all cases that are in conformance with models.

get_summary()[source]

Return Conformance overview data.

diagnostics()[source]

Return the diagnostic per case.

Example

>>> pm = PepperMining()
>>> pm.read_event_log_csv("/tests/data/eventlog-example.csv", separator=';', format_date='%d/%m/%Y %H:%M')
>>> pm.read_cases_csv("/tests/data/case-example.csv", separator=';')
>>> data = {'activity': ['register request', 'check ticket', 'examine casually', 'decide', 'pay compensation'], 'sorting': [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]}
>>> df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=['activity', 'sorting'])
>>> md = ProcessModel()
>>> md.set_process_model(df)
>>> c = Conformance(pm, md)
>>> c.get_cases()
>>> c.get_summary()
>>> c.diagnostics()
diagnostics() → DataFrame[source]

Return the diagnostic per case.

Returns:

DataFrame with the diagnosticas data. Columns: case_id: Case identification diagnostic: dictionary with DeepDiff results.

More information in: https://zepworks.com/deepdiff/current/index.html

Return type:

DataFrame

get_cases(kpi: list | None = None) → DataFrame[source]

Return all cases that are in conformance with models.

Parameters:

kpi (list(str)) – The a KPIs list. Choose the KPIs allow for the cases data. kpi = [‘NumberOfEvents’, ‘NumberOfActivities’, ‘Rework’]

Returns:

DataFrame with the Cases data.

Return type:

DataFrame

get_summary(kpi: list | None = ['NumberOfCases']) → DataFrame[source]

Return Conformance overview data.

Parameters:

kpi (list(str)) – The a KPIs list. Choose the KPIs allow for the conformance data. kpi = [‘NumberOfEvents’, ‘NumberOfActivities’, ‘NumberOfCases’, ‘AverageEventsPerCase’, ‘ThroughputTime’, ‘Rework’]

Returns:

DataFrame with the Conformance data.

Return type:

DataFrame

peppermining.conformance.process_model module

class peppermining.conformance.process_model.ProcessModel[source]

Bases: object

Process Model represent the ideal model that used in the identification of validations and conformance.

A Process Model is a depiction of the flow of work and tasks for specific goals. Process Models are important because they document existing processes and provide process knowledge. In the Pepper Mining the Process Model represent the ideal model, or the model that defines when the cases are in compliance. Each Process Model represent a process with Start and End.

set_process_model()[source]

Input Process Model data.

read_process_model_csv()[source]

Import the CSV to process model data.

get_process_model()[source]

Return Process Model data.

clear_datas()[source]

Clear Process Model.

Example

>>> data = {'activity': ['register request', 'check ticket', 'examine casually', 'decide', 'pay compensation'],
            'sorting': [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]}
>>> df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=['activity', 'sorting'])
>>> md = ProcessModel()
>>> md.set_process_model(df)
>>> md.get_process_model()
clear_datas() → None[source]

Clear Process Model.

Remove all rows and columns. After this method is possible include a new Process Model to the object.

get_process_model() → DataFrame[source]

Return Process Model data.

Returns:

DataFrame with the process model data.

Return type:

DataFrame

read_process_model_csv(file_path: str, separator: str | None = ';') → None[source]

Import the CSV to process model data.

Import the CSV into a pandas DataFrame. Convert the CSV into an process model Pandas DataFrame. The first step is to import the CSV file and internal API validate and convert it to the process model. See more infomation in the pandas documentation.

Parameters:

  • file_path (str) – Any valid string path is acceptable.

  • separator (str) – Delimiter used in CSV file.

Example

>>> md = ProcessModel()
>>> md.read_process_model_csv("tests/data/processmodel-example.csv", separator=';')
>>> md.get_process_model()

See also

https

//pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.read_csv.html?highlight=read_csv#

set_process_model(p_data: DataFrame) → None[source]

Input Process Model data.

Parameters:

p_data (pd.DataFrame) – DataFrame with ‘activity’ and ‘sorting’ columns.

Example

>>> data = {'activity': ['register request', 'check ticket', 'examine casually', 'decide', 'pay compensation'],
            'sorting': [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]}
>>> df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=['activity', 'sorting'])
>>> md = ProcessModel()
>>> md.set_process_model(df)
>>> md.get_process_model()

peppermining.conformance.root_cause_analysis module

peppermining.conformance.root_cause_analysis.root_cause_analysis(data: PepperMining | PepperFilter, top: int | None = 5) → DataFrame[source]

Root Cause Analysis of an event log.

The root cause analysis aims to find process errors and their causes and analyze them. These analyses make it possible to determine the proportion of errors found that have the same cause. Automated root cause analysis, consisting in analysing the cases attributes and return the most frequent datas.

Parameters:

  • pepper_data – It this should be a PepperMining or PepperFilter object.

  • top (int, Default: 5) – Choose the number of top frequent datas.

Example

>>> pm = PepperMining()
>>> ...
>>> root_cause_analysis(pm)
